message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a threatened abortion, which means there is vaginal bleeding but no cervical dilation or expulsion of products of conception. Complete abortion would involve complete expulsion of all products of conception, while an incomplete abortion involves partial expulsion with evidence of retained products of conception. Inevitable abortion involves cervical dilation with no tissue expulsion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has vaginal bleeding and no fetal tissue is seen, but a viable fetus with a normal heart rate is noted on ultrasound. This suggests a threatened abortion, which means that the patient is at risk of having a miscarriage. The other options suggest different stages of miscarriage with more definitive features, such as an incomplete abortion with retained fetal parts or an inevitable abortion with cervical dilation and fetal expulsion in progress.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest threatened abortion, which is bleeding during pregnancy without cervical dilation or passage of tissue. The presence of a viable fetus with a normal heart rate suggests incomplete or complete abortion is not present. Inevitable abortion would mean cervical dilation with intact membranes and vaginal bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has vaginal bleeding and closed cervical os, but a viable fetus with a normal heart rate is seen on ultrasound. This is consistent with a threatened abortion, which is defined as vaginal bleeding during the first 20 weeks of pregnancy with a closed cervical os and a viable fetus. Incomplete abortion would have incomplete passage of products of conception, and inevitable abortion would have cervical dilation and rupture of membranes. Complete abortion would have complete expulsion of products of conception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing threatened abortion, which is indicated by vaginal bleeding in the first half of pregnancy, with the cervical os remaining closed and a viable fetus with a normal heart rate noted on ultrasound. Incomplete abortion would involve an open cervical os and the retention of some products of conception. Inevitable abortion would involve an open cervical os but with no identified products of conception. Complete abortion would involve the passage of all products of conception with a closed cervical os.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has vaginal bleeding and a closed cervical os, which suggests a threatened abortion. An incomplete abortion would have products of conception remaining in the uterus, while a complete abortion would have passed all the products of conception. An inevitable abortion suggests that the process is ongoing and cannot be stopped.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has bleeding but no cervical dilation and a viable fetus with normal heart rate on ultrasound. This suggests a threatened abortion, which means bleeding in the first half of pregnancy without any cervical dilation or expulsion of any of the fetal or placental tissue. Incomplete abortion is when part of the fetal or placental tissue is expelled but some remains in the uterus, inevitable abortion is when the cervix is dilating and fetal or placental tissue is being expelled, and complete abortion is when all the fetal and placental tissue is expelled.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding but the cervical os is closed, and a viable fetus with a normal heart rate is noted on the ultrasound. These findings suggest a threatened abortion, which means that there is vaginal bleeding during pregnancy with a closed cervical os and no expulsion of products of conception. Incomplete abortion involves cervical dilation with expulsion of some but not all products of conception, inevitable abortion involves cervical dilation with an unviable fetus still in the uterus, and complete abortion involves expulsion of all products of conception.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has vaginal bleeding and a closed cervical os, indicating a threatened abortion. There is no evidence of fetal tissue being passed, ruling out incomplete or complete abortion. The presence of a viable fetus with a normal heart rate on ultrasound also rules out inevitable abortion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding during the second trimester of pregnancy, indicating threatened abortion. The fact that a viable fetus with a normal heart rate is noted on ultrasound and the cervical os is closed suggest that a miscarriage has not yet occurred. In incomplete abortion, some fetal tissue remains in the uterus, while in complete abortion all of the tissue is expelled. In inevitable abortion, passage of the products of conception is inevitable and the cervical os is open.
